issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares the attribute numberOfTutors as int, and the exercise asks students to implement setters/getters consistent with that. In the solution, the field is declared as short and the setter/constructor accept short, while the getter returns int. This creates an attribute/signature mismatch between the problem specification and the solution (and an internal inconsistency in the solution between the field type and some accessor signatures). Students reading the UML will implement numberOfTutors as int (and expect setter parameter and constructor parameter types to be int), but the solution uses short, which may confuse graders or students comparing their implementation to the reference.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type of numberOfTutors consistent across all artifacts. The simplest fix is to change the solution to use int for the field, constructor parameter, and setter parameter (i.e., private int numberOfTutors; constructor and setter take int), matching the UML and the expected getter/setter signatures. Alternatively, update the UML/problem statement to specify short everywhere if short is intentional — but prefer int for consistency with the rest of the numeric attributes.
